alert.note: Alert for Bannock; Bear Lake; Bingham; Blaine; Bonneville; Butte; Caribou; Cassia; Clark; Custer; Franklin; Fremont; Jefferson; Lincoln; Madison; Minidoka; Oneida; Power; Teton (Idaho) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 08 at 12:38PM MDT by NWS Pocatello
info.description: ...WARMING TEMPERATURES WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SNOW MELT AND POTENTIAL FLOODING... Significant warming temperatures will accelerate the melting of low and even some mid-level snowpack through early next week. Temperatures through the weekend will creep up into the 40s and 50s for many locations, which will aid in priming the snowpack to begin or accelerate melting. Temperatures will increase to near or just above normal by Monday and Monday night. Lows Monday night will likely remain above freezing for most locations below 6500ft elevation, which could exacerbate runoff from melting. While most of the flooding potential will be as a result of runoff in low-lying locations, snowmelt in the foothill areas will also increase flow on small creeks and streams including some larger streams that feed into mainstem rivers. Clear snow, ice and debris from culverts and other flow paths to allow runoff to flow away from buildings and other vulnerable infrastructure. Move deep snow away from the foundations of buildings and move equipment, and livestock out of poorly drained or low lying areas. Stay tuned for the latest river forecasts. Currently the river forecast for the Portneuf river at Pocatello is to rise just below action stage Wednesday into Thursday. The Bear River at the Wyoming/Idaho border is forecasted to respond to snow melt as well. Though the current forecast for the Bear River is still well below action stage. Remember, if you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around don`t drown, you never know what road conditions are hidden under the water.
